liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An Israeli citizen and Australian resident has spoken of his fears for cousins who remain missing after the weekend's devasting terror attack by Hamas. Darwin man Tai Bahar said he and other family members had no way of knowing what happened to his cousins who were at the Supernova music festival. "That is the hard thing but with all this happening right now, there is so much uncertainty, with everything going on and they have been missing for over three days," he told ABC News Channel. "There is no way to know what they have been through, what is going on and where they are." Mr Bahar also spoke of his relief that friends in Kfa Azza kibbutz, 5km outside Gaza, who had to hide in their safe room with their children when terrorists came and started shooting, are now safe. " My friend, her husband and her two kids - one is three years old and the other one is a year old and they had to hide in the safe room as the terrorists arrived into the Kibbutz, her husband held the door because the secure room is designed for bomb attacks, not for anyone trying to infiltrate," he said. "They had to manually hold the door to keep it safe and he held that for 27 hours as they tried to shoot at the door, trying to put all the furniture and burn them so they could go and kill them or whatever," "They hid there for 27 hours. You can imagine having a 3-year-old and young baby, that is unimaginable."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli in Australia says friends had to hide for 27 hours when terrorists started shooting

mediaThumbnail.caption: Tai Bahar is an Israeli citizen with residency in Australia, who has family and friends affected by the attacks.

Darwin man
Tai Bahar
said he and other family members had no way of knowing what happened to his cousins who were at the
Supernova music festival.
"That is the hard thing but with all this happening right now, there is so much uncertainty, with everything going on and they have been missing for over three days," he told ABC News Channel.
"There is no way to know what they have been through, what is going on and where they are."
Mr Bahar also spoke of his relief that friends in
Kfa Azza kibbutz
, 5km outside Gaza, who had to hide in their safe room with their children when terrorists came and started shooting, are now safe.

" My friend, her husband and her two kids - one is three years old and the other one is a year old and they had to hide in the safe room as the terrorists arrived into the Kibbutz, her husband held the door because the secure room is designed for bomb attacks, not for anyone trying to infiltrate," he said.

"They had to manually hold the door to keep it safe and he held that for 27 hours as they tried to shoot at the door, trying to put all the furniture and burn them so they could go and kill them or whatever,"
"They hid there for 27 hours. You can imagine having a 3-year-old and young baby, that is unimaginable."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NSW police has announced an operation to co-ordinate the reponse to demonstrations and events relating to the Hamas attack. NSW Acting Commissioner David Hudson says Operation Shelter will capture all intelligence available on community sentiment, potential protest activity and potential demonstrations. "This is not ideal that we have to take the steps to co-ordinate our activity across the state," he said. "There has been a fair bit of activity over the past few days which we believe will continue into the foreseeable future. "I think it is incumbent upon us to stand up to this standalone operation to co-ordinate activities not just within the city region but also across the broader state of New South Wales." Acting Commissioner Hudson says the intent of the operation is to "ensure community safety". "We will take any steps to ensure that," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW police announces Operation Shelter to 'ensure community safety'

NSW Acting Commissioner David Hudson says Operation Shelter will capture all intelligence available on community sentiment, potential protest activity and potential demonstrations.
"This is not ideal that we have to take the steps to co-ordinate our activity across the state," he said.
"There has been a fair bit of activity over the past few days which we believe will continue into the foreseeable future.
"I think it is incumbent upon us to stand up to this standalone operation to co-ordinate activities not just within the city region but also across the broader state of New South Wales."
Acting Commissioner Hudson says the intent of the operation is to "ensure community safety".
"We will take any steps to ensure that," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are growing concerns for the lives of women and children in Gaza, with the Red Crescent warning the situation was catastrophic. Palestinian Red Crescent Society spokesperson Nebal Farsakh said Israel’s bombardment was taking a huge toll in Gaza. "We have dealt with around 300 fatalities as well as 1,200 injuries," she said. "Those are our teams who were able to deal with, while according to the Ministry of Health, around 900 Palestinians lost their lives among those 240 children and many are women." She also said air strikes and bombardments were taking place without enough warning for the residents to be evacuated in time. "We ourselves, our medical teams on many occasions it has happened, when we were evacuating families due to air strikes, the same second when we were in the building trying to evacuate people, another Israeli air strike hit the location and thank God by miracle, our team could save their lives,” she said. "The situation is dangerous, our team are working under very dangerous conditions due to the escalation and the continued bombardment in every single part of Gaza." She warned around 200,000 Palestinians have now been displaced and they are lacking basic humanitarian needs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Red Crescent says Israeli air strikes are hitting as workers evacuate families

mediaThumbnail.caption: Nebal Farsakh from Palestinian Red Crescent Society has raised concerns the city will run out of fuel and electricity in five days while hospitals struggle with lack of medical supplies.

items.synopsis: It’s become a well-used rallying cry by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people at marches and events and the term "sovereignty" has been brought up a lot throughout this referendum debate but there’s more to this term than you might realise – let's unpack it.

title.children: Have you heard the chant 'sovereignty never ceded'? Do you know what it means?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has spoken from Uluru with former MP Pat Farmer. Mr Farmer has just completed a 14,500km run throughout Australia in support of the Voice to Parliament. "He began on the south island when we farewelled him in Hobart in April and at that time, I pledged to join with him on this day in October," Mr Albanese said. "He has provided an inspiration for Australians and what he has done is, in running 14,500km to ask his fellow Australians to just walk a few metres, walk into a polling booth and write Y-E-S on the ballot paper on the referendum." Mr Farmer said his mammoth run led to much time thinking of Indigenous history. "I am glad to be at this point in the world's time where we start to acknowledge Indigenous communities right around the world and the significance of that culture," Mr Farmer said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM speaks from Uluru with former MP Pat Farmer after 14,000km run

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese speaking from Uluru
(ABC News)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
has spoken from Uluru with former
MP Pat Farmer
Mr Farmer has just completed a
14,500km run throughout Australia in support of the Voice to Parliament
"He began on the south island when we farewelled him in Hobart in April and at that time, I pledged to join with him on this day in October," Mr Albanese said.

"He has provided an inspiration for Australians and what he has done is, in running 14,500km to ask his fellow Australians to just walk a few metres, walk into a polling booth and write Y-E-S on the ballot paper on the referendum."
Mr Farmer said his mammoth run led to much time thinking of Indigenous history.
"I am glad to be at this point in the world's time where we start to acknowledge Indigenous communities right around the world and the significance of that culture," Mr Farmer said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In a couple of hours we'll hear Western Australian senator Patrick Dodson 's National Press Club address. Mr Dodson is also the special envoy for reconciliation and implementation of the Uluru Statement from the Heart. Previously, Mr Dodson was director of the Central and Kimberley Land Councils and a Commissioner in the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. His address will begin at 12:30pm AEDT. We'll be bringing you a live stream as well as blogging Mr Dodson's address.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Patrick Dodson to address National Press Club

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier we told you about the 25 Australians of the Year that had put their name on a open letter urging a Yes vote on Saturday. Here is their open letter in full : As Australians of the Year, past and present, we wish to indicate our heartfelt support for a constitutionally enshrined Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice and respectfully urge Australians to vote 'Yes' in the upcoming referendum on October 14th. We respect the generous invitation extended within the Uluru Statement from the Heart to come together to recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the Australian Constitution, and ensure that they have a voice in government decision-making, especially in matters that impact on their daily realities. The Uluru statement responds to over two centuries of dispossession, pain and suffering with generosity and love. As First Peoples of this nation, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples' enduring connection with Australia stretches back for 60 thousand years, and represents the unique, intrinsic essence of our past, present and future. This truth has been ignored and denied until the very recent past, and we now are at a fork in the road. We must choose the high road to inclusiveness and respect. The low road leads us into a shameful dead end, with unimaginable consequences for our national identity and self respect. Many other nations with colonial histories similar to ours, notably Canada, Norway and New Zealand have already taken the high road. So we know that a mutually advantageous outcome is possible. Since colonisation Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have been subjected to 235 years of destructive or ineffectual policies, which have had devastating impacts on cultural integrity and a slew of social and health outcomes. The effective exclusion of indigenous voices from decision-making has been at best useless and costly and, at worst, damaging, blocking any meaningful progress. There is overwhelming evidence that, when given a voice, services are effective and lead to improvements in outcomes, as happened during the Covid pandemic. The Voice is about ensuring that our First Nations people have a genuine say in matters that impact on their lives. For too long they have been worse than powerless. A Yes vote in this referendum represents a once in a lifetime opportunity to secure inclusion and respect, to empower, to make long overdue progress towards closing the gap, and to finally bring all of us together as Australians on a level playing field. It is not about giving one community an advantage but about reducing a severe and unacceptable level of disadvantage and discrimination. A Yes vote is a step to a more united and cohesive nation, conscious of the past and looking together to the future.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australians of the Year Yes vote letter in full

children.content: Earlier we told you about the
25 Australians of the Year
that had put their name on a open letter urging a Yes vote on Saturday.
Here is their
open letter in full

As Australians of the Year, past and present, we wish to indicate our heartfelt support for a constitutionally enshrined Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice and respectfully urge Australians to vote 'Yes' in the upcoming referendum on October 14th.

We respect the generous invitation extended within the Uluru Statement from the Heart to come together to recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the Australian Constitution, and ensure that they have a voice in government decision-making, especially in matters that impact on their daily realities. The Uluru statement responds to over two centuries of dispossession, pain and suffering with generosity and love.

As First Peoples of this nation, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples' enduring connection with Australia stretches back for 60 thousand years, and represents the unique, intrinsic essence of our past, present and future. This truth has been ignored and denied until the very recent past, and we now are at a fork in the road. We must choose the high road to inclusiveness and respect. The low road leads us into a shameful dead end, with unimaginable consequences for our national identity and self respect.
Many other nations with colonial histories similar to ours, notably Canada, Norway and New Zealand have already taken the high road. So we know that a mutually advantageous outcome is possible.

Since colonisation Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have been subjected to 235 years of destructive or ineffectual policies, which have had devastating impacts on cultural integrity and a slew of social and health outcomes. The effective exclusion of indigenous voices from decision-making has been at best useless and costly and, at worst, damaging, blocking any meaningful progress. There is overwhelming evidence that, when given a voice, services are effective and lead to improvements in outcomes, as happened during the Covid pandemic.

The Voice is about ensuring that our First Nations people have a genuine say in matters that impact on their lives. For too long they have been worse than powerless. A Yes vote in this referendum represents a once in a lifetime opportunity to secure inclusion and respect, to empower, to make long overdue progress towards closing the gap, and to finally bring all of us together as Australians on a level playing field. It is not about giving one community an advantage but about reducing a severe and unacceptable level of disadvantage and discrimination. A Yes vote is a step to a more united and cohesive nation, conscious of the past and looking together to the future.

items.synopsis: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has continued to defy public pressure to immediately step down, by announcing he will retire next year, while the Australian share market has risen for its fifth day in a row as concerns about higher-for-longer interest rates subsided. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas board set for a shakeup as Richard Goyder becomes the latest high-profile exit, ASX rises for fifth straight day

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has been a mainstay in the headlines for months now, and pressure has been slowly but steadily mounting on the airline's board — and specifically Richard Goyder — to step down after one of the most tumultuous periods in its history. There's been the flight credits saga, delayed and cancelled flights, customer service complaints, a class action, and an ACCC investigation over allegations it sold tickets for cancelled flights. But that was only the beginning — on top of Alan Joyce's early exit, the High Court's ruling that Qantas illegally sacked 1,700 ground crew, and the multi-million dollar payout for Joyce and its executives disclosed in its annual report. And it was just two weeks ago today that Richard Goyder, along with CEO Vanessa Hudson and Qantas' general counsel Andrew Finch, appeared at a Senate inquiry into the federal government's blocking of additional Qatar Airways flights. It was in that fiery hearing that Richard Goyder said not once, but twice, that he had the support of Qantas shareholders ( despite shareholders withdrawing their support for him a day earlier, and putting the rest of the board on notice ). As the popular saying goes, timing is everything — so why has Richard Goyder made the announcement now, when his exit isn't until sometime next year? The ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan has unpacked what the timing means, how it will impact next month's annual general meeting in Melbourne, and how Qantas might move forward. You can watch his full assessment of the situation below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📺 What's behind the timing of Qantas chair Richard Goyder's exit announcement?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Transport Workers' Union has wasted no time in criticising Richard Goyder's retirement plans announced this morning, saying he's attempting "to retire in dignity after presiding over illegal conduct". The TWU's statement references the High Court's unanimous ruling that Qantas acted illegally when it sacked about 1,700 ground crew and replaced them with contractors during the COVID-19 pandemic. The union says Mr Goyder should follow former CEO Alan Joyce in an early exit from the airline this year. TWU national secretary Michael Kaine believes Mr Goyder should depart sooner rather than later so he doesn't escape accountability, and allow for a total governance reset at the airline. "This announcement is an attempt by Goyder to leave in a dignified manner with another year's pay in his pocket, after presiding over the largest case of illegal sackings in Australian history," Mr Kaine said. "This isn't genuine board renewal, this is just shuffling the deckchairs. We need to put an end to illegal conduct being blindly rubber-stamped by a board that fails to scrutinise the CEO who is treated as their equal by having a place on the board. "With no worker representation, Qantas governance has ignored the needs of the workforce and decimated jobs and standards. " A fresh start for Qantas governance requires a new board composition that excludes the CEO and embeds a worker representative to avoid the repeat of colossal errors of judgement being repeated."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Goyder's exit from Qantas is 'just shuffling the deckchairs', Transport Workers' Union says

"This announcement is

"This isn't genuine board renewal,
this is just shuffling the deckchairs
. We need to put an end to illegal conduct being blindly rubber-stamped by a board that fails to scrutinise the CEO who is treated as their equal by having a place on the board.
"With no worker representation,
Qantas governance has ignored the needs of the workforce
and decimated jobs and standards.
A fresh start for Qantas governance requires a new board composition that excludes the CEO
and embeds a worker representative
to avoid the repeat of colossal errors of judgement being repeated."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has risen for its fifth straight day, with the materials and industrial sectors driving the gains. The ASX 200 had risen 0.5% to 7,076 points by 10:20am AEDT. Some of today's best performing stocks include Sayona Mining (+5%), Paladin Energy (+4.2%) and Core Lithium (+4.1%). Qantas shares gained 0.8% to $4.94, after the airline said its chairman Richard Goyder would retire in one year's time — resisting public pressure for him to step down immediately. On the flip side, shares of Bank of Queensland fell 3.6%. This was after the bank reported its statutory full-year profit plunged 70 per cent to $124 million. BoQ also cut its final dividend to 21 cents per shares (down from 24 cents last year). Shares of Life360 (-2.7%), Regis Resources (-1.9%) and Magellan Financial (-1.7%) also suffered heavy losses.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX rises in morning trade, along with Qantas shares

image.altText: A composite image of Brodie Grundy, Jade Gresham and Lachie Schultz.

items.synopsis: Sydney will need to get creative to find a way to get both Taylor Adams and Brodie Grundy through the door, while Fremantle won't let Lachie Schultz leave cheaply. Get the latest news, analysis and discussion in our live blog.

title.children: Swans face stalemate in big-name trades, Freo play hard ball with wantaway gun forward

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While it's probably a bit of a feeler, do you think that Collingwood's purported offer of pick 19 for Lachie Schultz, considering the comments from Peter Bell, is a bit disingenuous for both Schults and Fremantle, or do you think it's a fair offer? - MikeP. I don't think it's miles away, but it's not going to be enough. If I know Peter Bell and Fremantle, they will be waiting to see what Collingwood get back for Taylor Adams and will then be asking for both that and pick 19. That is probably too far the other way, but if a deal is to be done it will probably end up somewhere in the middle of that. There have also been reports that Freo are trying to stack up 2024 picks for a crack at some big-name recruits — Logan McDonald is the one most commonly mentioned — so perhaps that is something they might ask for from Collingwood. For all of Bell's comments that Freo are prepared to hold Schultz to his contract, I'm quite sure a deal will be done at some point between now and next Wednesday night.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How close are Collingwood to Lachie Schultz?

children.content: While it's probably a bit of a feeler, do you think that Collingwood's purported offer of pick 19 for Lachie Schultz, considering the comments from Peter Bell, is a bit disingenuous for both Schults and Fremantle, or do you think it's a fair offer?
- MikeP
I don't think it's miles away, but it's not going to be enough.
(Getty Images)

If I know Peter Bell and Fremantle, they will be waiting to see what Collingwood get back for Taylor Adams and will then be asking for both that and pick 19. That is probably too far the other way, but if a deal is to be done it will probably end up somewhere in the middle of that.

There have also been reports that Freo are trying to stack up 2024 picks for a crack at some big-name recruits — Logan McDonald is the one most commonly mentioned — so perhaps that is something they might ask for from Collingwood.
For all of Bell's comments that Freo are prepared to hold Schultz to his contract, I'm quite sure a deal will be done at some point between now and next Wednesday night.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Happy Wednesday Dean
If both Melbourne and Collingwood want Pick 25 for Grundy and Adams respectively, will this be a one or the other type scenario or will they both get done? Who do you think the Swans need more if they can only have one? - Chris G.. A couple of really interesting questions there. I do think they'll find a way to get both deals done. They'll likely need to deep into their future picks a little, but from my vantage point pick 25 feels like it should be used on Adams, and given the Demons are pretty keen to see Grundy head out the door, pick 33 (and a little something else) should be the foundations of a deal there. The Swans might need a little bit back to make sure they have enough points to match an inevitable bid for academy player Caiden Cleary on draft night, but they should have enough capital to keep everyone happy. But the second question is the really interesting one. From a list perspective, Grundy is the one they need most. Tom Hickey's retirement has left Peter Ladhams as the only real ruck option on the list, so that's a hole they badly need to fill. In saying that, I reckon Adams would have a huge impact in that Swans midfield. When fit and firing he is still a fantastic player, and a perfect foil for the likes of Warner, Gulden and Florent in the Sydney engine room.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How do Sydney get their Grundy and Adams deals done?

children.content:
Happy Wednesday Dean
If both Melbourne and Collingwood want Pick 25 for Grundy and Adams respectively, will this be a one or the other type scenario or will they both get done? Who do you think the Swans need more if they can only have one?
- Chris G.
A couple of really interesting questions there.
(Getty Images)

I do think they'll find a way to get both deals done. They'll likely need to deep into their future picks a little, but from my vantage point pick 25 feels like it should be used on Adams, and given the Demons are pretty keen to see Grundy head out the door, pick 33 (and a little something else) should be the foundations of a deal there.

The Swans might need a little bit back to make sure they have enough points to match an inevitable bid for academy player Caiden Cleary on draft night, but they should have enough capital to keep everyone happy.

But the second question is the really interesting one. From a list perspective, Grundy is the one they need most. Tom Hickey's retirement has left Peter Ladhams as the only real ruck option on the list, so that's a hole they badly need to fill.

In saying that, I reckon Adams would have a huge impact in that Swans midfield. When fit and firing he is still a fantastic player, and a perfect foil for the likes of Warner, Gulden and Florent in the Sydney engine room.

image.altText: a outback shelter with cars and charging and solar panels

items.synopsis: There are not many electric car chargers along one of Australia's longest roads, but one local company has developed a prototype it hopes will help range anxiety in the outback.

title.children: 'It's very novel': Could this portable charger with solar panels solve range anxiety in the outback?

image.altText: The ruins of houses and buildings sit among the grey rubble of other destroyed buildings.

items.synopsis: As attacks from both sides escalate and the death toll rises, there are fears people will be trapped in Gaza with no humanitarian corridor after further air strikes leave neighbourhoods reduced to rubble.

title.children: Israel destroys whole Gaza neighbourhoods as defence minister tells his forces offensive will 'intensify'

image.altText: Israeli soldiers carry the body of a victim of an attack by militants from Gaza .

items.synopsis: Israeli soldiers begin the grim work of collecting the bodies of those killed in Hamas' terror attack as rockets continue to fly overhead.

title.children: Killed 'in their beds and protection rooms': Inside Kfar Aza kibbutz after Hamas terrorists attacked

image.altText: Chinese flags near the logo Evergrande Centre in Shanghai, China, on September 24, 2021.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest trading partner is facing its biggest economic slowdown in decades, and the Reserve Bank has warned that stress in China's economy will be felt across the world — including here in Australia.

title.children: How a 'sharp deterioration' in China's property market could affect housing affordability in Australia

image.altText: Chris Minns stands at a school yard

items.synopsis: A protest organiser with the Palestinian Action Group Sydney said they would launch a legal challenge after Chris Minns shut down a through the city this Sunday.

title.children: Minns says planned pro-Palestinian rally will not be allowed to 'commandeer Sydney streets'

image.altText: A woman sits on a park bench and looks at her phone.

items.synopsis: The telecommunications watchdog releases its annual report card on the country's telcos, and while complaints are down across the board, there’s one notable exception — Optus.

title.children: 'I don't have time to be fixing up big companies' errors': Industry report shows rise of complaints about Optus

image.altText: Justin Choveaux stands with another firefighter next to a vegetation fire at night.

items.synopsis: A key group representing Queensland's volunteer fire brigades pours water on the idea of a "semi-professional firefighting service" akin to the Army Reserve, saying it could alienate those already tackling this year's bushfire season.

title.children: Rural brigades boss hoses down talk of national firefighting force

image.altText: A young woman wearing sunglasses looks out a car window

items.synopsis: Tasmania's public housing overcrowding rates are higher than the national average and continue to grow, with one family in Hobart's northern suburbs given priority status still waiting after four years.

title.children: Katlyn's been told she can't get a bigger house for her growing family, so she drives around looking for one

image.altText: A medium shot of a man supported by a cable while dangling from a platform under a bridge, over water with a man on the platform

items.synopsis: Mike Heard completed 500 more jumps than his previous record, and credits much of his success to working on his mental health.

title.children: New Zealand man bungee jumps 941 times in one day to reclaim world record

image.altText: A woman and a young man stand next to each other arm in arm

items.synopsis: Russell Martin, who lives with dementia, jokes that he's learned a trick or two from Mother and Son's eccentric matriarch Maggie, but does the show reflect the reality of living with the condition?

title.children: The original Mother and Son never mentioned dementia. Why not then, and why now?

image.altText: A young woman with dark skin and black hair wearing yellow headphones looks at a yellow smartphone

items.synopsis: While some are optimistic about the streaming giant's move into audiobooks, others fear it will threaten authors' already precarious livelihoods.

title.children: Authors fear Spotify's move into audiobooks risks 'killing the golden goose'

image.altText: A soldier in military uniform and holding a gun stands in front of a destroyed apartment building with emergency crews.

items.synopsis: To prepare their soldiers for the psychological challenges of combat, the Ukrainian military has developed a sophisticated resilience training program. Its insights may be very valuable to other militaries — including the ADF, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's military has invested heavily in resilience training. The ADF should take note

image.altText: Close up shot of a woman's hands clasped on a lap

items.synopsis: Historic legislation is set to be introduced in Queensland today, with Hannah Clarke's parents praising the new protection for victims.

title.children: Lucy followed her husband's directions in hopes he'd love her more, until she realised she was being coercively controlled

image.altText: A man underwater in full commercial diving gear, holding a chainsaw.

items.synopsis: Underwater chainsawing, welding and oxy-arc cutting are not skills on many people's radars. But they can be a gateway to a new career, a commercial diving instructor says.

title.children: Commerical dive training isn't 'swimming around looking at fish.' There's power tools and work to be done

image.altText: A man in a cap and glasses.

items.synopsis: Alan Leslie Graham was 79 at the time he was last seen in April 2016 at Angepena Station during a prospecting trip to SA's far north, and the state's coroner is now trying to piece together his final movements from witness testimonies.

title.children: Shoe sole and abandoned van among clues in outback disappearance of gold prospector

image.altText: Afghan men carry on their shoulders the body of a woman earthquake victim, wrapped in black cloth.

items.synopsis: As the search for survivors ends, relief efforts are underway and in an area of Afghanistan that was badly hit in an earthquake earlier this year, even beggars are donating what they can to help.

title.children: Afghanistan pleads for help after deadly earthquake reduced villages to rubble and dust

image.altText: Silhouette of a man standing on a shoreline at sunset looking out at an oil rig on the ocean.

items.synopsis: It could take hundreds of years — if not thousands — to reverse decline to ocean fish habitat if warming's not kept below climate targets, according to new research.

title.children: A 'double whammy' for fish — and humans — if climate targets are overshot

image.altText: A man looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Aboriginal people are considering what the Voice might mean for them, and if they want it at all. The ABC visited several regional communities in Queensland and listened. Here's what they had to say.

title.children: Fred has 'lost a lot of white friends' in the lead up to the referendum. He hopes they can reconcile their differences

image.altText: Mohammad Rizwan raises his bat and helmet during a Cricket World Cup match.

items.synopsis: Ireland's time at the top of the World Cup record books is over after Pakistan eclipsed a 12-year-old mark for the highest run chase in World Cup history, notching 4-345 to take down Sri Lanka.

title.children: Pakistan breaks World Cup record with mammoth chase, while Stokes misses another England clash

image.altText: Elska Mia with her clear harp sits on backstage steps. She wears a glittery dress, pink lipstick and blue boots.

items.synopsis: Elska kept a dark chapter of her life hidden for years. Through her music, she's finally been able to tell that story.

title.children: Through art, I'm finally giving a voice to a dark chapter in my life
